instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos and all you other nice people

well i have a 4924 that according to the customer had some water on it ... I guess she is right but absolutely no corrosion on the board whatsoever.
It has green/orange light and the pp3v42 is actually 3.32v (bit low?) and the ppbus is 4.2v and the only thing getting a bit warm (not hot) is the cpu.
The area around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> looks as the rest of the board like new , unfortunately absolutely no corrosion anywhere .
The board is taking 350 mA ....
Any tips where to turn :)

Thank you all for any tips

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
Lot of current for a board witout <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Bad news if CPU heats in this conditions.

Remove F7140 until you will get correct voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR>.
If you still note heating CPU, it could be damaged through RTC power rail, derivated from <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>.
<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> heats too?
Check voltage and diode mode at its pin 1.

Also check exact resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 19, 20, 27.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
Thank you so much 2informaticos

Removed F7140 and i got the correct voltage on <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> 12.58V , and the cpu does not get warm anymore . The board now takes 0.073V
And YES the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> does get hot !!!!
Voltage on pin 1 is 0.226V and diode mode beeeeeeps

resistance 17/18 is 3.6 Ohm
resistance 27/28 is 20.9 Ohm

<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> voltages
pin 1 = 3.5V
pin 2 = 17.61V
pin 3 = 0 V
pin 9 = 0.031 V
pin 12 = 3.34 V
pin 13 = 3.29 V
pin 15 = 0.046 V
pin 19 = 5.506 V
pin 20 = 5.506 V
pin 27 = 0.001 V

it seems like <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> gets a bit warm as well on my Flir , but the precision is not the best on it (its the one attachable to the phone) so it could be something around it.

Thanks again for your answer

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
"Voltage on pin 1 is 0.226V and diode mode beeeeeeps "
What is the exact ohm value?
Remove <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and check again.

"pin 3 = 0 V "
Post diode mode there.
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and check if voltage goes up.
If yes, resolder F7140 and check diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; do NOT apply power if get strange value!
If still low, check <RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR>; if good, replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
the exact value is 1.3 Ohm
removed the <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and the value is the same .

Pin 3 on isl in diode mode is 0.003 V
Removed <CAPACITOR>C7111</CAPACITOR> and the voltage did not go up .
<RESISTOR>R7110</RESISTOR> is 41.3 kOhm ... a bit low maybe ?
I will try to replace <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> ......

I was completely on the wrong way .... i thought since <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> got hot that it was the problem since with F7140 removed I got the correct value on <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> i thought <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> was ok .
Thanks

small update , replaced the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and the values are back to as before ppbus 4.03V and the board still takes 0.354 A... the only difference is that L7130 gets hot now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
"resolder F7140 and check diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; do NOT apply power if get strange value! "
???

Do you get correct <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> after changing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is now 4.48 V after changing the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> so at least that is now ok :)
Diode mode on ppbus is 0.176 V

removed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and measured all the pins and found short on the following pins: 1 , 2 , 5

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
What is the exact ohm value to ground at pin 1?
Remove <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and test again.
If still low, there are 3 caps more, <CAPACITOR>C8090</CAPACITOR>-92.
If none bad, then dead CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ppbus stuck at 4v
threads.message:
The exact ohm value is 1.4 Ohm to ground on pin 1 . Even with the <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> removed it is shorted ... does that mean that the short is in the board , since the <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is removed as well ? It seems that I will have to give up on this one . The <CAPACITOR>C8090</CAPACITOR>-92 are ok (unfortunately) .
Thank you 2 informaticos for all your help . 
Are you the only moderator left on the forum ? All the latest posts i notice that you take , it must be a lot of pressure only on you , not fair .
Have a nice day and all the best to you
